We created two stacked bar charts to illustrate our findings: The first one is an overall Based on our first stacked bar chart Content Classification of Vignettes, we could tell that there are more vignettes in categories like Work/Education, Discrimination and Misc, and there are relatively less vignettes in Health/Accident than other categories. For content in regard to Discrimination and Finances, there are a larger portion of students that feel high level of stress. This founding makes sense since college students are typically young adults that lack financial literacy and economic stability, and race has always been a sensitive issue that causes stress on people and especially young people. There is a larger portion of students that are indifferent about content (when stress severity = 0) related to Interpersonal Tension and Health/Accident, which also makes sense, considering that college students are typically in good health and rarely need to worry about complicated working relationships, or any relationships in general, so interpersonal tension and health may be least of their worries, comparing to other issues. However, it surprises me that there is also a larger portion of students that are indifferent about content related to Discrimination, which may indicate that some people may be less conscious about issues relating to race, while there are also a large percentage of people that are very conscious about that. Based on our first stacked bar chart Content Classification of Vignettes, the survey in Session 2 seems to reflect an overall lower level of stress comparing to the results from Session 1, also we can find an interesting twist in our second graph Content Classification Frequency, where the position of Health/Accident and Work/Education swapped when sorting by the percentage of most severe level of stress, which may be effected by external factors such as the time period where our survey were conducted.
